div.head: Act 1, Scene 1
div.stage: Athens. A hall in Timon's house.
Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: Good day, sir.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: I am glad y' are well.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: I have not seen you long: how goes the world?

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: It wears, sir, as it grows.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: Ay, that's well known:
But what particular rarity? what strange,
Which manifold record not matches? See,
Magic of bounty! all these spirits thy power
Hath conjured to attend. I know the merchant.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: I know them both; th' other's a jeweller.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: O, 'tis a worthy lord.

sp.speaker: Jeweller
sp.l: Nay, that's most fixed.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were,
To an untirable and continuate goodness:
He passes.

sp.speaker: Jeweller
sp.l: I have a jewel here —

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: O, pray, let's see't: for the Lord Timon, sir?

sp.speaker: Jeweller
sp.l: If he will touch the estimate: but, for that —

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: “When we for recompense have praised the vile,
It stains the glory in that happy verse
Which aptly sings the good.”

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: 'Tis a good form. Looking at the jewel.

sp.speaker: Jeweller
sp.l: And rich: here is a water, look ye.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication
To the great lord.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: A thing slipped idly from me.
Our poesy is as a gum, which oozes
From whence 'tis nourished: the fire i' the flint
Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame
Provokes itself and like the current flies
Each bound it chases. What have you there?

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir.
Let's see your piece.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: 'Tis a good piece.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: So 'tis: this comes off well and excellent.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: Indifferent.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: Admirable: how this grace
Speaks his own standing! what a mental power
This eye shoots forth! how big imagination
Moves in this lip to the dumbness of the gesture
One might interpret.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: It is a pretty mocking of the life.
Here is a touch; is't good?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: I will say of it,
It tutors nature: artificial strife
Lives in these touches, livelier than life. Enter certain Senators, and pass over.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: How this lord is followed!

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: The senators of Athens: happy men!

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: Look, more!

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: You see this confluence, this great flood of visitors.
I have, in this rough work, shaped out a man,
Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug
With amplest entertainment: my free drift
Halts not particularly, but moves itself
In a wide sea of wax: no levelled malice
Infects one comma in the course I hold;
But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on,
Leaving no tract behind.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: How shall I understand you?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: I will unbolt to you.
You see how all conditions, how all minds,
As well of glib and slippery creatures as
Of grave and austere quality, tender down
Their services to Lord Timon: his large fortune
Upon his good and gracious nature hanging
Subdues and properties to his love and tendance
All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-faced flatterer
To Apemantus, that few things loves better
Than to abhor himself: even he drops down
The knee before him and returns in peace
Most rich in Timon's nod.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: I saw them speak together.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill
Feigned Fortune to be throned: the base o' the mount
Is ranked with all deserts, all kind of natures,
That labour on the bosom of this sphere
To propagate their states: amongst them all,
Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fixed,
One do I personate of Lord Timon's frame,
Whom fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her;
Whose present grace to present slaves and servants
Translates his rivals.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: 'Tis conceived to scope.
This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks,
With one man beckoned from the rest below,
Bowing his head against the steepy mount
To climb his happiness, would be well expressed
In our condition.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: Nay, sir, but hear me on.
All those which were his fellows but of late,
Some better than his value, on the moment
Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance,
Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear,
Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him
Drink the free air.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: Ay, marry, what of these?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood
Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependents
Which laboured after him to the mountain's top
Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down,
Not one accompanying his declining foot.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: 'Tis common:
A thousand moral paintings I can show
That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's
More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well
To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen
The foot above the head. Trumpets sound. Enter LORD TIMON, addressing himself courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from VENTIDIUS talking with him: LUCILIUS and other servants following.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Imprisoned is he, say you?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Ay, my good lord: five talents is his debt,
His means most short, his creditors most strait:
Your honourable letter he desires
To those have shut him up; which failing,
Periods his comfort.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Noble Ventidius! Well;
I am not of that feather to shake off
My friend when he must need me. I do know him
A gentleman that well deserves a help:
Which he shall have: I'll pay the debt, and free him.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Your lordship ever binds him.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Commend me to him: I will send his ransom;
And being enfranchised, bid him come to me.
'Tis not enough to help the feeble up,
But to support him after. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: All happiness to your honour! Exit. Enter an old Athenian.

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Freely, good father.

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: I have so: what of him?

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Attends he here, or no? Lucilius!

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: Here, at your lordship's service.

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature,
By night frequents my house. I am a man
That from my first have been inclined to thrift;
And my estate deserves an heir more raised
Than one which holds a trencher.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Well; what further?

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: One only daughter have I, no kin else,
On whom I may confer what I have got:
The maid is fair, a' the youngest for a bride,
And I have bred her at my dearest cost
In qualities of the best. This man of thine
Attempts her love: I prithee, noble lord,
Join with me to forbid him her resort;
Myself have spoke in vain.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: The man is honest.

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: Therefore he will be, Timon:
His honesty rewards him in itself;
It must not bear my daughter.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Does she love him?

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: She is young and apt:
Our own precedent passions do instruct us
What levity's in youth.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Love you the maid?

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: If in her marriage my consent be missing,
I call the gods to witness, I will choose
Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world,
And dispossess her all.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: How shall she be endowed,
If she be mated with an equal husband?

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: Three talents on the present; in future, all.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: This gentleman of mine hath served me long:
To build his fortune I will strain a little,
For 'tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter:
What you bestow, in him I'll counterpoise,
And make him weigh with her.

sp.speaker: Athenian
sp.l: Most noble lord,
Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: My hand to thee; mine honour on my promise.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: Humbly I thank your lordship: never may
That state or fortune fall into my keeping,
Which is not owed to you! Exeunt Lucilius and Old Athenian.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: Vouchsafe my labour, and long live your lordship!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: I thank you; you shall hear from me anon:
Go not away. What have you there, my friend?

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: A piece of painting, which I do beseech
Your lordship to accept.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Painting is welcome.
The painting is almost the natural man;
For since dishonour traffics with man's nature,
He is but outside: these pencilled figures are
Even such as they give out. I like your work;
And you shall find I like it: wait attendance
Till you hear further from me.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: The gods preserve ye!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Well fare you, gentleman: give me your hand:
We must needs dine together. Sir, your jewel
Hath suffered under praise.

sp.speaker: Jeweller
sp.l: What, my lord! dispraise?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: A mere satiety of commendations.
If I should pay you for't as 'tis extolled,
It would unclew me quite.

sp.speaker: Jeweller
sp.l: My lord, 'tis rated
As those which sell would give: but you well know,
Things of like value differing in the owners
Are prized by their masters: believe't, dear lord,
You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Well mocked.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: No, my good lord; he speaks the common tongue,
Which all men speak with him.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Look, who comes here: will you be chid? Enter APEMANTUS.

sp.speaker: Jeweller
sp.l: We'll bear, with your lordship.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: He'll spare none.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus!

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.l: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow;
When thou art Timon's dog, and these knaves honest.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Why dost thou call them knaves? thou know'st them not.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Are they not Athenians?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Yes.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Then I repent not.

sp.speaker: Jeweller
sp.ab: You know me, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Thou know'st I do: I called thee by thy name.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Whither art going?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: To knock out an honest Athenian's brains.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: That's a deed thou'lt die for.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Right, if doing nothing be death by the law.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: How likest thou this picture, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: The best, for the innocence.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Wrought he not well that painted it?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: He wrought better that made the painter; and yet he's
but a filthy piece of work.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.ab: Y' are a dog.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Thy mother's of my generation: what's she, if I be a
dog?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: No; I eat not lords.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: And thou shouldst, thou'ldst anger ladies.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: O, they eat lords; so they come by great bellies.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: That's a lascivious apprehension.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: So thou apprehendest it: take it for thy labour.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Not so well as plain-dealing, which will not cast a
man a doit.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: What dost thou think 'tis worth?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Not worth my thinking. How now, poet!

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.ab: How now, philosopher!

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.ab: Art not one?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Yes.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.ab: Then I lie not.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Art not a poet?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.ab: Yes.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Then thou liest: look in thy last work, where thou
hast feigned him a worthy fellow.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.ab: That's not feigned; he is so.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for
thy labour: he that loves to be flattered is
worthy o' the flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: E'en as Apemantus does now; hate a lord with my heart.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: What, thyself?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Ay.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: That I had no angry wit to be a lord. Art not thou a
merchant?

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.ab: Ay, Apemantus.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not!

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.ab: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Traffic's thy god; and thy god confound thee!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: What trumpet's that?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: 'Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse,
All of companionship.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Pray, entertain them; give them guide to us. Exeunt some Attendants.
You must needs dine with me: go not you hence
Till I have thanked you: when dinner's done,
Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights. Enter ALCIBIADES, with the rest.
Most welcome, sir!

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.l: So, so, there!
Aches contract and starve your supple joints!
That there should be small love 'mongst these sweet knaves,
And all this courtesy! The strain of man's bred out
Into baboon and monkey.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feed
Most hungerly on your sight.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Right welcome, sir!
Ere we depart, we'll share a bounteous time
In different pleasures. Pray you, let us in. Exeunt all except Apemantus. Enter two Lords.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: What time a' day is't, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Time to be honest.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: That time serves still.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: The more accursed thou, that still omitt'st it.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Thou art going to Lord Timon's feast?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Why, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean to give
thee none.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Hang thyself!

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding: make thy
requests to thy friend.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Away, unpeaceable dog, or I'll spurn thee hence!

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: I will fly, like a dog, the heels a' the ass.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: He's opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in,
And taste Lord Timon's bounty? he outgoes
The very heart of kindness.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: He pours it out; Plutus, the god of gold,
Is but his steward: no meed, but he repays
Sevenfold above itself; no gift to him,
But breeds the giver a return exceeding
All use of quittance.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: The noblest mind he carries
That ever governed man.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: I'll keep you company. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 2
div.stage: A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet served in; FLAVIUS and others attending;
then enter LORD TIMON, ALCIBIADES, Lords, Senators, and VENTIDIUS. Then comes, dropping after all, APEMANTUS, discontentedly, like himself.

sp.speaker: Ventidius
sp.l: Most honoured Timon,
It hath pleased the gods to remember my father's age,
And call him to long peace.
He is gone happy, and has left me rich:
Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound
To your free heart, I do return those talents,
Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help
I derived liberty.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: O, by no means,
Honest Ventidius; you mistake my love:
I gave it freely ever; and there's none
Can truly say he gives, if he receives:
If our betters play at that game, we must not dare
To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.

sp.speaker: Ventidius
sp.l: A noble spirit!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Nay, my lords, They all stand ceremoniously looking on Timon.
Ceremony was but devised at first
To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,
Recanting goodness, sorry ere 'tis shown;
But where there is true friendship, there needs none.
Pray, sit; more welcome are ye to my fortunes
Than my fortunes to me. They sit.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: My lord, we always have confessed it.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.l: Ho, ho, confessed it! hanged it, have you not?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.l: No;
You shall not make me welcome:
I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Fie, th' art a churl; ye 've got a humour there
Does not become a man; 'tis much to blame.
sp.ab: They say, my lords, “ira furor brevis est;” but
yond man is very angry. Go, let him have a table
by himself, for he does neither affect company, nor is
he fit for't, indeed.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon: I come to
observe; I give thee warning on't.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: I take no heed of thee; th' art an Athenian,
therefore welcome: I myself would have no power;
prithee, let my meat make thee silent.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: I scorn thy meat; 'twould choke me, for I should
ne'er flatter thee. O you gods, what a number of
men eats Timon, and he sees 'em not! It grieves
me to see so many dip their meat in one man's
blood; and all the madness is, he cheers them up too.
sp.l: I wonder men dare trust themselves with men:
Methinks they should invite them without knives;
Good for their meat, and safer for their lives.
sp.ab: There's much example for't; the fellow that sits
next him now, parts bread with him, pledges the
breath of him in a divided draught, is the readiest
man to kill him: 't has been proved. If I were a huge
man, I should fear to drink at meals;
sp.l: Lest they should spy my windpipe's dangerous notes:
Great men should drink with harness on their throats.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: My lord, in heart; and let the health go round.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Flow this way! A brave fellow he keeps his tides
well. Those healths will make thee and thy state look
ill, Timon.
sp.l: Here's that which is too weak to be a sinner,
Honest water, which ne'er left man i' the mire:
This and my food are equals; there's no odds;
Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods, Apemantus' grace.
Immortal gods, I crave no pelf;
I pray for no man but myself:
Grant I may never prove so fond,
To trust man on his oath or bond;
Or a harlot, for her weeping;
Or a dog, that seems a-sleeping;
Or a keeper with my freedom,
Or my friends, if I should need 'em.
Amen. So fall to't:
Rich men sin, and I eat root. Eats and drinks.
Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Captain Alcibiades, your heart's in the field now.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.ab: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than a
dinner of friends.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.ab: So they were bleeding new, my lord, there's no
meat like 'em: I could wish my best friend at such a
feast.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Would all those flatterers were thine enemies
then, that then thou mightst kill 'em and bid me to
'em!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that
you would once use our hearts, whereby we might
express some part of our zeals, we should think
ourselves for ever perfect.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods
themselves have provided that I shall have much
help from you: how had you been my friends else?
why have you that charitable title from thousands,
did not you chiefly belong to my heart? I have
told more of you to myself than you can with
modesty speak in your own behalf; and thus far
I confirm you. O you gods, think I, what need we
have any friends, if we should ne'er have need
of 'em? they were the most needless creatures
living, should we ne'er have use for 'em, and
would most resemble sweet instruments hung up in
cases that keeps their sounds to themselves. Why,
I have often wished myself poorer, that I might
come nearer to you. We are born to do benefits:
and what better or properer can we call our own
than the riches of our friends? O, what a precious
comfort 'tis, to have so many, like brothers,
commanding one another's fortunes! O joy's, e'en
made away ere't can be born! Mine eyes cannot
hold out water, methinks: to forget their faults, I
drink to you.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Thou weep'st to make them drink, Timon.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Joy had the like conception in our eyes
And at that instant like a babe sprung up.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.l: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.l: I promise you, my lord, you moved me much.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.l: Much! Tucket, within.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: What means that trump? Enter a Servant.
How now?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: Please you, my lord, there are certain ladies most
desirous of admittance.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Ladies! what are their wills?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord,
which bears that office, to signify their pleasures.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: I pray, let them be admitted.

sp.speaker: Cupid
sp.l: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all
That of his bounties taste! The five best senses
Acknowledge thee their patron; and come freely
To gratulate thy plenteous bosom: There
Taste, touch all, pleased from thy table rise;
They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: They're welcome all; let 'em have kind admittance:
Music, make their welcome! Exit Cupid.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: You see, my lord, how ample y' are beloved. Music. Re-enter CUPID, with a mask of Ladies as Amazons, with lutes in their hands, dancing and playing.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.l: Hoyday, what a sweep of vanity comes this way!
They dance! they are madwomen.
Like madness is the glory of this life,
As this pomp shows to a little oil and root.
We make ourselves fools, to disport ourselves;
And spend our flatteries, to drink those men
Upon whose age we void it up again,
With poisonous spite and envy.
Who lives that's not depraved or depraves?
Who dies, that bears not one spurn to their graves
Of their friends' gift?
I should fear those that dance before me now
Would one day stamp upon me: 't has been done;

Men shut their doors against a setting sun. The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of TIMON; and to show their loves, each singles out an Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: You have done our pleasures much grace, fair ladies,
Set a fair fashion on our entertainment,
Which was not half so beautiful and kind;
You have added worth unto't and lustre,
And entertained me with mine own device;
I am to thank you for't.

sp.speaker: First Lady
sp.l: My lord, you take us even at the best.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: 'Faith, for the worst is filthy; and would not hold
taking, I doubt me.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you:
Please you to dispose yourselves.

sp.speaker: All Ladies
sp.l: Most thankfully, my lord. Exeunt Cupid and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Flavius.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: The little casket bring me hither.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: Yes, my lord. More jewels yet! Aside.
There is no crossing him in's humour;
Else I should tell him well, i' faith, I should,
When all's spent, he'ld be crossed then, and he could.
'Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind
That man might ne'er be wretched for his mind. Exit.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Where be our men?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here, my lord, in readiness.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Our horses! Re-enter FLAVIUS, with the casket.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: O my friends, I have one word
To say to you: look you, my good lord,
I must entreat you, honour me so much
As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it,
Kind my lord.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: I am so far already in your gifts, —

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: So are we all. Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord, there are certain nobles of the senate
Newly alighted, and come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: They are fairly welcome.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: I beseech your honour,
Vouchsafe me a word; it does concern you near.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Near! why then, another time I'll hear thee:
I prithee, let's be provided to show them entertainment.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: I scarce know how. Enter a second Servant.

sp.speaker: Second Servant
sp.l: May it please your honour, Lord Lucius,
Out of his free love, hath presented to you
Four milk-white horses, trapped in silver.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: I shall accept them fairly; let the presents
Be worthily entertained. Enter a third Servant.
How now! what news?

sp.speaker: Third Servant
sp.ab: Please you, my lord, that honourable gentleman,
Lord Lucullus, entreats your company to-morrow
to hunt with him, and has sent your honour two brace
of greyhounds.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: I'll hunt with him; and let them be received,
Not without fair reward.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: What will this come to?
He commands us to provide, and give great gifts,
And all out of an empty coffer:
Nor will he know his purse, or yield me this,
To show him what a beggar his heart is,
Being of no power to make his wishes good:
His promises fly so beyond his state
That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes
For every word; he is so kind that he now
Pays interest for't; his land's put to their books.
Well, would I were gently put out of office
Before I were forced out!
Happier is he that has no friend to feed
Than such that do e'en enemies exceed.
I bleed inwardly for my lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: You do yourselves
Much wrong, you bate too much of your own merits:
Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.l: O, he's the very soul of bounty!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: And now I remember, my lord, you gave
Good words the other day of a bay courser
I rode on: 'tis yours, because you liked it.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: O, I beseech you, pardon me my lord, in that.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: You may take my word, my lord; I know, no man
Can justly praise but what he does affect:
I weigh my friend's affection with mine own;
I'll tell you true. I'll call to you.

sp.speaker: All Lords
sp.l: O, none so welcome.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: I take all and your several visitations
So kind to heart, 'tis not enough to give;
Methinks, I could deal kingdoms to my friends,
And ne'er be weary. Alcibiades,
Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich:
It comes in charity to thee: for all thy living
Is 'mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast
Lie in a pitched field.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: Ay, defiled land, my lord.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: We are so virtuously bound —

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: And so
Am I to you.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: So infinitely endeared —

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: All to you. Lights, more lights!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: The best of happiness,
Honour and fortunes, keep with you, Lord Timon!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Ready for his friends. Exeunt all but Apemantus and Timon.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.l: What a coil's here!
Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums!
I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums
That are given for 'em. Friendship's full of dregs:
Methinks, false hearts should never have sound legs.
Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on curtsies.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen,
I would be good to thee.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: No, I'll nothing: for if I should be bribed too,
there would be none left to rail upon thee, and
then thou wouldst sin the faster. Thou givest so
long, Timon, I fear me thou wilt give away thyself
in paper shortly: what needs these feasts, pomps and
vainglories?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Nay, and you begin to rail on society once, I am
sworn not to give regard to you. Farewell; and come
with better music.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: So. Thou wilt not hear me now; thou shalt not then.
I'll lock thy heaven from thee.

lg.l: O, that men's ears should be
To counsel deaf, but not to flattery! Exit.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 1
div.stage: A Senator's house.
Enter Senator, with papers in his hand.

sp.speaker: Senator
sp.l: And late, five thousand: to Varro and to Isidore
He owes nine thousand; besides my former sum,
Which makes it five and twenty. Still in motion
Of raging waste? It cannot hold; it will not.
If I want gold, steal but a beggar's dog,
And give it Timon, why, the dog coins gold.
If I would sell my horse, and buy twenty more
Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon,
Ask nothing, give it him, it foals me, straight,
And able horses. No porter at his gate,
But rather one that smiles and still invites
All that pass by. It cannot hold; no reason
Can sound his state in safety. Caphis, ho!
Caphis, I say! Enter CAPHIS.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: Here, sir; what is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Senator
sp.l: Get on your cloak, and haste you to Lord Timon;
Importune him for my moneys; be not ceased
With slight denial, nor then silenced when —
“Commend me to your master” — and the cap
Plays in the right hand, thus: but tell him,
My uses cry to me, I must serve my turn
Out of mine own; his days and times are past
And my reliances on his fracted dates
Have smit my credit: I love and honour him,
But must not break my back to heal his finger;
Immediate are my needs, and my relief
Must not be tossed and turned to me in words,
But find supply immediate. Get you gone:
Put on a most importunate aspect,
A visage of demand! for, I do fear,
When every feather sticks in his own wing,
Lord Timon will be left a naked gull,
Which flashes now a phoenix. Get you gone.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: I go, sir.

sp.speaker: Senator
sp.l: Ay, go, sir! — Take the bonds along with you,
And have the dates in. Come!

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Senator
sp.l: Go. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 2
div.stage: The same. A hall in Timon's house.
Enter FLAVIUS, with many bills in his hand.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: No care, no stop! so senseless of expense,
That he will neither know how to maintain it,
Nor cease his flow of riot: takes no account
How things go from him, nor resumes no care
Of what is to continue: never mind
Was to be so unwise, to be so kind.
What shall be done? he will not hear, till feel:
I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting.
Fie, fie, fie, fie! Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of ISIDORE and VARRO.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: Good even, Varro: what,
You come for money?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Is't not your business too?

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: It is: and yours too, Isidore?

sp.speaker: Isidore's Servant
sp.l: It is so.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: Would we were all discharged!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I fear it.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: Here comes the lord. Enter TIMON, ALCIBIADES, and Lords, c.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: So soon as dinner's done, we'll forth again,
My Alcibiades. With me? what is your will?

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: My lord, here is a note of certain dues.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Dues! Whence are you?

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: Of Athens here, my lord.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Go to my steward.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: Please it your lordship, he hath put me off
To the succession of new days this month:
My master is awaked by great occasion
To call upon his own, and humbly prays you
That with your other noble parts you'll suit
In giving him his right.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Mine honest friend,
I prithee, but repair to me next morning.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: Nay, good my lord, —

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Contain thyself, good friend.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: One Varro's servant, my good lord, —

sp.speaker: Isidore's Servant
sp.l: From Isidore;
He humbly prays your speedy payment.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.l: If you did know, my lord, my master's wants —

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks
And past.

sp.speaker: Isidore's Servant
sp.l: Your steward puts me off, my lord;
And I am sent expressly to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Give me breath.
I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on;
I'll wait upon you instantly. Exeunt Alcibiades and Lords. To Flav. Come hither: pray you.
How goes the world, that I am thus encountered
With clamorous demands of debt, broken bonds,
And the detention of long since due debts,
Against my honour?

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: Please you, gentlemen,
The time is unagreeable to this business:
Your importunacy cease till after dinner,
That I may make his lordship understand
Wherefore you are not paid.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Do so, my friends. See them well entertained. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.ab: Pray, draw near.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.ab: Stay, stay, here comes the fool with Apemantus: let's
ha' some sport with 'em.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: Hang him, he'll abuse us.

sp.speaker: Isidore's Servant
sp.ab: A plague upon him, dog!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: How dost, fool?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Dost dialogue with thy shadow?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: I speak not to thee.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: No, 'tis to thyself.
Come away.

sp.speaker: Isidore's Servant
sp.ab: There's the fool hangs on your back already.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: No, thou stand'st single, th' art not on him yet.

sp.speaker: Caphis
sp.ab: Where's the fool now?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: He last asked the question. Poor rogues, and usurers'
men! bawds between gold and want!

sp.speaker: All Servants
sp.ab: What are we, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Asses.

sp.speaker: All Servants
sp.ab: Why?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: That you ask me what you are, and do not know
yourselves. Speak to 'em, fool.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: How do you, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: All Servants
sp.ab: Gramercies, good fool: how does your mistress?

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: She's e'en setting on water to scald such chickens as
you are. Would we could see you at Corinth!

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Good! gramercy.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Look you, here comes my master's page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Why, how now, captain! what do you in this wise
company? How dost thou, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Would I had a rod in my mouth, that I might answer
thee profitably.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Prithee, Apemantus, read me the superscription of
these letters: I know not which is which.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Canst not read?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: No.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: There will little learning die then. that day
thou art hanged. This is to Lord Timon; this to
Alcibiades. Go; thou wast born a bastard, and thou't
die a bawd.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Thou wast whelped a dog, and thou shalt famish a dog's
death. Answer not; I am gone.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: E'en so thou outrunnest grace. Fool, I will go with
you to Lord Timon's.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Will you leave me there?

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: If Timon stay at home. You three serve three usurers?

sp.speaker: All Servants
sp.ab: Ay; would they served us!

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: So would I, — as good a trick as ever hangman served
thief.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Are you three usurers' men?

sp.speaker: All Servants
sp.ab: Ay, fool.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: I think no usurer but has a fool to his servant:
my mistress is one, and I am her fool. When men
come to borrow of your masters, they approach
sadly, and go away merry; but they enter my
master's house merrily, and go away sadly: the reason
of this?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: I could render one.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Do it then, that we may account thee a whoremaster
and a knave; which notwithstanding, thou shalt be no
less esteemed.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: What is a whoremaster, fool?

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: A fool in good clothes, and something like thee.
'Tis a spirit: sometime't appears like a lord;
sometime like a lawyer; sometime like a philosopher,
with two stones moe than's artificial one: he is
very often like a knight; and, generally, in all
shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore to
thirteen, this spirit walks in.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: Thou art not altogether a fool.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: Nor thou altogether a wise man: as much foolery as I
have, so much wit thou lack'st.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: That answer might have become Apemantus.

sp.speaker: All Servants
sp.ab: Aside, aside; here comes Lord Timon.

sp.speaker: Apemantus
sp.ab: Come with me, fool, come.

sp.speaker: Fool
sp.ab: I do not always follow lover, elder brother and woman;
sometime the philosopher.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: Pray you, walk near; I'll speak with you anon. Exeunt Servants.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: You make me marvel: wherefore ere this time
Had you not fully laid my state before me,
That I might so have rated my expense,
As I had leave of means?

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: You would not hear me,
At many leisures I proposed.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Go to:
Perchance some single vantages you took,
When my indisposition put you back;
And that unaptness made your minister,
Thus to excuse yourself.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: O my good lord,
At many times I brought in my accounts,
Laid them before you; you would throw them off,
And say, you found them in mine honesty.
When, for some trifling present, you have bid me
Return so much, I have shook my head and wept;
Yea, 'gainst the authority of manners, prayed you
To hold your hand more close: I did endure
Not seldom, nor no slight checks, when I have
Prompted you in the ebb of your estate
And your great flow of debts. My loved lord,
Though you hear now, too late — yet now's a time —
The greatest of your having lacks a half
To pay your present debts.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Let all my land be sold.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: 'Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone;
And what remains will hardly stop the mouth
Of present dues: the future comes apace:
What shall defend the interim? and at length
How goes our reckoning?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: O my good lord, the world is but a word:
Were it all yours to give it in a breath,
How quickly were it gone!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: You tell me true.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: If you suspect my husbandry or falsehood,
Call me before the exactest auditors
And set me on the proof. So the gods bless me,
When all our offices have been oppressed
With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept
With drunken spilth of wine, when every room
Hath blazed with lights and brayed with minstrelsy,
I have retired me to a wasteful cock,
And set mine eyes at flow.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Prithee, no more.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: Heavens, have I said, the bounty of this lord!
How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants
This night englutted! Who is not Timon's?
What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is Lord Timon's?
Great Timon, noble, worthy, royal Timon!
Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise,
The breath is gone whereof this praise is made:
Feast-won, fast-lost; one cloud of winter showers,
These flies are couched.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Come, sermon me no further;
No villainous bounty yet hath passed my heart;
Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given.
Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack,
To think I shall lack friends? Secure thy heart;
If I would broach the vessels of my love,
And try the argument of hearts by borrowing,
Men and men's fortunes could I frankly use
As I can bid thee speak.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: Assurance bless your thoughts!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: And, in some sort, these wants of mine are crowned,
That I account them blessings; for by these
Shall I try friends: you shall perceive how you
Mistake my fortunes; I am wealthy in my friends.
Within there! Flaminius! Servilius! Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants.

sp.speaker: Servants
sp.ab: My lord? my lord?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: I will dispatch you severally; you to Lord Lucius;
to Lord Lucullus you: I hunted with his honour
to-day: you, to Sempronius: commend me to their
loves, and, I am proud, say, that my occasions
have found time to use 'em toward a supply of money:
let the request be fifty talents.

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.ab: As you have said, my lord.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.ab: Lord Lucius and Lucullus? hum!

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Go you, sir, to the senators —
Of whom, even to the state's best health, I have
Deserved this hearing — bid 'em send o' the instant
A thousand talents to me.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: I have been bold —
For that I knew it the most general way —
To them to use your signet and your name;
But they do shake their heads, and I am here
No richer in return.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Is't true? can't be?

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: They answer, in a joint and corporate voice,
That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot
Do what they would; are sorry — you are honourable, —
But yet they could have wished — they know not —
Something hath been amiss — a noble nature
May catch a wrench — would all were well — 'tis pity; —
And so, intending other serious matters,
After distasteful looks, and these hard fractions,
With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods
They froze me into silence.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: You gods, reward them!
Prithee, man, look cheerly. These old fellows
Have their ingratitude in them hereditary:
Their blood is caked, 'tis cold, it seldom flows;
'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind;
And nature, as it grows again toward earth,
Is fashioned for the journey, dull and heavy. To a Serv.
Go to Ventidius. To Flav. Prithee, be not sad,
Thou art true and honest; ingeniously I speak,
No blame belongs to thee. To Ser.
Ventidius lately
Buried his father; by whose death he's stepped
Into a great estate: when he was poor,
Imprisoned and in scarcity of friends,
I cleared him with five talents: greet him from me;
Bid him suppose some good necessity
Touches his friend, which craves to be remembered
With those five talents Exit Serv.
. To Flav. That had, give't these fellows
To whom 'tis instant due. Ne'er speak, or think,
That Timon's fortunes 'mong his friends can sink.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: I would I could not think it: that thought is bounty's foe;
Being free itself, it thinks all others so. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 1
div.stage: A room in Lucullus' house.
FLAMINIUS waiting.
Enter a Servant to him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: I have told my lord of you; he is coming down to you.

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.ab: I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: Here's my lord.

sp.speaker: Lucullus
sp.ab: One of Lord Timon's men? a gift, I warrant. Why,
this hits right; I dreamt of a silver basin and
ewer to-night. Flaminius, honest Flaminius; you
are very respectively welcome, sir. Fill me some
wine.
And how does that honourable, complete, free-hearted
gentleman of Athens, thy very bountiful good lord and
master?

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.ab: His health is well, sir.

sp.speaker: Lucullus
sp.ab: I am right glad that his health is well, sir:
and what hast thou there under thy cloak, pretty
Flaminius?

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.ab: 'Faith, nothing but an empty box, sir; which, in
my lord's behalf, I come to entreat your honour
to supply; who, having great and instant occasion
to use fifty talents, hath sent to your lordship
to furnish him, nothing doubting your present
assistance therein.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.ab: La, la, la, la! “nothing doubting,” says he?
Alas, good lord! a noble gentleman 'tis, if he
would not keep so good a house. Many a time and
often I ha' dined with him, and told him on't,
and come again to supper to him, of purpose to
have him spend less, and yet he would embrace no
counsel, take no warning by my coming. Every man
has his fault, and honesty is his: I ha' told him
on't, but I could ne'er get him from't.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: Please your lordship, here is the wine.

sp.speaker: Lucullus
sp.ab: Flaminius, I have noted thee always wise. Here's to
thee.

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.ab: Your lordship speaks your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lucullus
sp.ab: I have observed thee always for a towardly prompt
spirit — give thee thy due — and one that knows what
belongs to reason; and canst use the time well,
if the time use thee well: good parts in thee.
Get you gone, sirrah
Draw nearer, honest Flaminius. Thy lord's a
bountiful gentleman: but thou art wise; and thou
knowest well enough, although thou comest to me,
that this is no time to lend money, especially
upon bare friendship, without security. Here's
three solidares for thee: good boy, wink at me, and
say thou sawest me not. Fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.l: Is't possible the world should so much differ,
And we alive that lived? Fly, damned baseness,
To him that worships thee! Throwing the money back.

sp.speaker: Lucullus
sp.ab: Ha! now I see thou art a fool, and fit for thy master.

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.l: May these add to the number that may scald thee!
Let molten coin be thy damnation,
Thou disease of a friend, and not himself!
Has friendship such a faint and milky heart,
It turns in less than two nights? O you gods,
I feel my master's passion! this slave,
Unto his honour, has my lord's meat in him:
Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment,
When he is turned to poison?
O, may diseases only work upon't!
And, when he's sick to death, let not that part of nature
Which my lord paid for, be of any power
To expel sickness, but prolong his hour! Exit.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 2
div.stage: A public place.
Enter Lucius, with three Strangers.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.ab: Who, the Lord Timon? he is my very good friend, and an
honourable gentleman.

sp.speaker: First Stranger
sp.ab: We know him for no less, though we are but
strangers to him. But I can tell you one thing,
my lord, and which I hear from common rumours:
now Lord Timon's happy hours are done and past, and
his estate shrinks from him.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.ab: Fie, no, do not believe it; he cannot want for money.

sp.speaker: Second Stranger
sp.ab: But believe you this, my lord, that, not long
ago, one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus
to borrow so many talents, nay, urged extremely
for't and showed what necessity belonged to't, and yet
was denied.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.ab: How!

sp.speaker: Second Stranger
sp.ab: I tell you, denied, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.ab: What a strange case was that! now, before the
gods, I am ashamed on't. Denied that honourable
man! there was very little honour showed in't.
For my own part, I must needs confess, I have
received some small kindnesses from him, as money,
plate, jewels and such like trifles, nothing
comparing to his; yet, had he mistook him and
sent to me, I should ne'er have denied his occasion so
many talents.

sp.speaker: Servilius
sp.ab: See, by good hap, yonder's my lord; I have sweat to
see his honour. My honoured lord, —

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.ab: Servilius! you are kindly met, sir. Fare thee
well: commend me to thy honourable virtuous lord, my
very exquisite friend.

sp.speaker: Servilius
sp.ab: May it please your honour, my lord hath sent —

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.ab: Ha! what has he sent? I am so much endeared to
that lord; he's ever sending: how shall I thank him,
thinkest thou? And what has he sent now?

sp.speaker: Servilius
sp.ab: He's only sent his present occasion now, my lord;
requesting your lordship to supply his instant use
with so many talents.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: I know his lordship is but merry with me;
He cannot want fifty five hundred talents.

sp.speaker: Servilius
sp.l: But in the meantime he wants less, my lord.
If his occasion were not virtuous,
I should not urge it half so faithfully.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.ab: Dost thou speak seriously, Servilius?

sp.speaker: Servilius
sp.ab: Upon my soul, 'tis true, sir.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.ab: What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish myself
against such a good time, when I might ha' shown
myself honourable! how unluckily it happened,
that I should purchase the day before for a little
part, and undo a great deal of honour! Servilius,
now, before the gods, I am not able to do, — the
more beast, I say: — I was sending to use Lord
Timon myself, these gentlemen can witness; but
I would not, for the wealth of Athens, I had
done't now. Commend me bountifully to his good
lordship; and I hope his honour will conceive
the fairest of me, because I have no power to be
kind: and tell him this from me, I count it one
of my greatest afflictions, say, that I cannot
pleasure such an honourable gentleman. Good
Servilius, will you befriend me so far as to use mine
own words to him?

sp.speaker: Servilius
sp.ab: Yes, sir, I shall.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: I'll look you out a good turn, Servilius. Exit Servilius.
True, as you said, Timon is shrunk indeed;
And he that's once denied will hardly speed. Exit.

sp.speaker: First Stranger
sp.l: Do you observe this, Hostilius?

sp.speaker: Second Stranger
sp.l: Ay, too well.

sp.speaker: First Stranger
sp.l: Why, this is the world's soul; and just of the same piece
Is every flatterer's sport. Who can call him
His friend that dips in the same dish? for, in
My knowing, Timon has been this lord's father,
And kept his credit with his purse,
Supported his estate; nay, Timon's money
Has paid his men their wages: he ne'er drinks,
But Timon's silver treads upon his lip;
And yet — O, see the monstrousness of man
When he looks out in an ungrateful shape! —
He does deny him, in respect of his,
What charitable men afford to beggars.

sp.speaker: Third Stranger
sp.l: Religion groans at it.

sp.speaker: First Stranger
sp.l: For mine own part,
I never tasted Timon in my life,
Nor came any of his bounties over me,
To mark me for his friend; yet, I protest,
For his right noble mind, illustrious virtue
And honourable carriage,
Had his necessity made use of me,
I would have put my wealth into donation,
And the best half should have returned to him,
So much I love his heart: but, I perceive,
Men must learn now with pity to dispense;
For policy sits above conscience. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 3
div.stage: A room in Sempronius' house.
Enter SEMPRONIUS, and a Servant of TIMON'S.

sp.speaker: Sempronius
sp.l: Must he needs trouble me in't, — hum!
— 'bove all others?
He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus;
And now Ventidius is wealthy too,
Whom he redeemed from prison: all these
Owes their estates unto him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord,
They have all been touched and found base metal,
For they have all denied him.

sp.speaker: Sempronius
sp.l: How! have they denied him?
Has Ventidius and Lucullus denied him?
And does he send to me? Three? hum!
It shows but little love or judgement in him:
Must I be his last refuge? His friends, like physicians,
Thrive, give him over: must I take the cure upon me?
He's much disgraced me in't; I'm angry at him,
That might have known my place: I see no sense for't.
But his occasions might have wooed me first;
For, in my conscience, I was the first man
That e'er received gift from him:
And does he think so backwardly of me now,
That I'll requite it last? No:
So it may prove an argument of laughter
To the rest, and 'mongst lords I be thought a fool.
I'ld rather than the worth of thrice the sum,
H'ad sent to me first, but for my mind's sake;
I'd such a courage to do him good. But now return,
And with their faint reply this answer join;
Who bates mine honour shall not know my coin. Exit.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: Excellent! Your lordship's a goodly villain. The
devil knew not what he did when he made man
politic; he crossed himself by't: and I cannot
think but, in the end, the villainies of man will
set him clear. How fairly this lord strives to
appear foul! takes virtuous copies to be wicked,
like those that under hot ardent zeal would set whole
realms on fire:
sp.l: Of such a nature is his politic love.
This was my lord's best hope; now all are fled,
Save only the gods: now his friends are dead,
Doors, that were ne'er acquainted with their wards
Many a bounteous year, must be employed
Now to guard sure their master.
And this is all a liberal course allows;
Who cannot keep his wealth must keep his house. Exit.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 4
div.stage: The same. A hall in Timon's house.
Enter two Servants of VARRO, and the Servant of LUCIUS, meeting TITUS, HORTENSIUS, and other Servants of TIMON'S creditors, waiting his coming out.

sp.speaker: Varro's Servant
sp.l: Well met: good morrow, Titus and Hortensius.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: The like to you, kind Varro.

sp.speaker: Hortensius
sp.l: Lucius!
What, do we meet together?

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Ay, and I think
One business does command us all; for mine
Is money.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: So is theirs and ours. Enter PHILOTUS.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: And Sir Philotus too!

sp.speaker: Philotus
sp.l: Good day at once.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Welcome, good brother.
What do you think the hour?

sp.speaker: Philotus
sp.l: Labouring for nine.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: So much?

sp.speaker: Philotus
sp.l: Is not my lord seen yet?

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Philotus
sp.l: I wonder on't; he was wont to shine at seven.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Ay, but the days are waxed shorter with him:
You must consider that a prodigal course
Is like the sun's; but not, like his, recoverable.
I fear 'tis deepest winter in Lord Timon's purse;
That is, one may reach deep enough, and yet
Find little.

sp.speaker: Philotus
sp.l: I am of your fear for that.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: I'll show you how to observe a strange event.
Your lord sends now for money.

sp.speaker: Hortensius
sp.l: Most true, he does.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: And he wears jewels now of Timon's gift,
For which I wait for money.

sp.speaker: Hortensius
sp.l: It is against my heart.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Mark, how strange it shows,
Timon in this should pay more than he owes:
And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels,
And send for money for 'em.

sp.speaker: Hortensius
sp.l: I'm weary of this charge, the gods can witness:
I know my lord hath spent of Timon's wealth,
And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth.

sp.speaker: Varro's Servant
sp.l: Yes, mine's three thousand crowns: what's yours?

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Five thousand mine.

sp.speaker: Varro's Servant
sp.l: 'Tis much deep: and it should seem by the sum,
Your master's confidence was above mine;
Else, surely, his had equalled. Enter FLAMINIUS.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: One of Lord Timon's men.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.ab: Flaminius! Sir, a word: pray, is my lord ready to come
forth?

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.ab: No, indeed, he is not.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.ab: We attend his lordship; pray, signify so much.

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.ab: I need not tell him that; he knows you are too
diligent.
sp.stage: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.ab: Ha! is not that his steward muffled so? He goes away
in a cloud: call him, call him.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.ab: Do you hear, sir?

sp.speaker: Second Servant
sp.ab: By your leave, sir, —

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.ab: What do ye ask of me, my friend?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: We wait for certain money here, sir.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: Ay,
If money were as certain as your waiting,
'Twere sure enough.
Why then preferred you not your sums and bills,
When your false masters eat of my lord's meat?
Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts
And take down the interest into their gluttonous maws.
You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up;
Let me pass quietly:
Believe't, my lord and I have made an end;
I have no more to reckon, he to spend.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Ay, but this answer will not serve.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: If 'twill not serve, 'tis not so base as you;
For you serve knaves. Exit.

sp.speaker: Varro's Servant
sp.ab: How! what does his cashiered worship mutter?

sp.speaker: Second Servant
sp.ab: No matter what; he's poor, and that's revenge
enough. Who can speak broader than he that has
no house to put his head in? such may rail against
great buildings.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.ab: O, here's Servilius; now we shall know some answer.

sp.speaker: Servilius
sp.ab: If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some
other hour, I should derive much from't; for,
take't of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to
discontent: his comfortable temper has forsook
him; he's much out of health, and keeps his chamber.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Many do keep their chambers are not sick:
And, if it be so far beyond his health,
Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts,
And make a clear way to the gods.

sp.speaker: Servilius
sp.l: Good gods!

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: We cannot take this for answer, sir.

sp.speaker: Flaminius
sp.l: Servilius, help! My lord! my lord! Enter TIMON, in a rage; FLAMINIUS following.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: What, are my doors opposed against my passage?
Have I been ever free, and must my house
Be my retentive enemy, my gaol?
The place which I have feasted, does it now,
Like all mankind, show me an iron heart?

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Put in now, Titus.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: My lord, here is my bill.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Here's mine.

sp.speaker: Hortensius
sp.l: And mine, my lord.

sp.speaker: Both Servants
sp.l: And ours, my lord.

sp.speaker: Philotus
sp.l: All our bills.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Knock me down with 'em: cleave me to the girdle.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Alas, my lord, —

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Cut my heart in sums.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Mine, fifty talents.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Tell out my blood.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Five thousand crowns, my lord.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Five thousand drops pays that. What yours? — and yours?

sp.speaker: Varro's Servant
sp.l: My lord, —

sp.speaker: Second Servant
sp.l: My lord, —

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you! Exit.

sp.speaker: Hortensius
sp.ab: 'Faith, I perceive our masters may throw their
caps at their money: these debts may well be called
desperate ones, for a madman owes 'em.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: They have e'en put my breath from me, the slaves.
Creditors? devils!

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: My dear lord, —

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: What if it should be so?

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: My lord, —

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: I'll have it so. My steward!

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: Here, my lord.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again.
Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius:
all.
I'll once more feast the rascals.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: O, my lord,
You only speak from your distracted soul;
There's not so much left, to furnish out
A moderate table.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Be it not in thy care; go,

lg.l: I charge thee, invite them all: let in the tide
Of knaves once more; my cook and I'll provide. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 5
div.stage: The same. The senatehouse The Senate sitting.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: My lord, you have my voice to't; the fault's
Bloody; 'tis necessary he should die:
Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.l: Most true; the law shall bruise 'em. Enter ALCIBIADES, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: Honour, health, and compassion to the senate!

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: Now, captain?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: I am an humble suitor to your virtues;
For pity is the virtue of the law,
And none but tyrants use it cruelly.
It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy
Upon a friend of mine, who, in hot blood,
Hath stepped into the law, which is past depth
To those that, without heed, do plunge into't.
He is a man, setting his fate aside,
Of comely virtues:
Nor did he soil the fact with cowardice —
An honour in him which buys out his fault —
But with a noble fury and fair spirit,
Seeing his reputation touched to death,
He did oppose his foe:
And with such sober and unnoted passion
He did behoove his anger, ere 'twas spent,
As if he had but proved an argument.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: You undergo too strict a paradox,
Striving to make an ugly deed look fair:
Your words have took such pains as if they laboured
To bring manslaughter into form and set quarrelling
Upon the head of valour; which indeed
Is valour misbegot and came into the world
When sects and factions were newly born:
He's truly valiant that can wisely suffer
The worst that man can breathe, and make his wrongs
His outsides, to wear them like his raiment, carelessly,
And ne'er prefer his injuries to his heart,
To bring it into danger.
If wrongs be evils and enforce us kill,
What folly 'tis to hazard life for ill!

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: My lord, —

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: You cannot make gross sins look clear:
To revenge is no valour, but to bear.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: My lords, then, under favour, pardon me,
If I speak like a captain.
Why do fond men expose themselves to battle,
And not endure all threats? sleep upon't,
And let the foes quietly cut their throats,
Without repugnancy? If there be
Such valour in the bearing, what make we
Abroad? why then, women are more valiant
That stay at home, if bearing carry it,
And the ass more captain than the lion, the fellow
Loaden with irons wiser than the judge,
If wisdom be in suffering. O my lords,
As you are great, be pitifully good:
Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood?
To kill, I grant, is sin's extremest gust;
But, in defence. by mercy, 'tis most just.
To be in anger is impiety;
But who is man that is not angry?
Weigh but the crime with this.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.l: You breathe in vain.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: In vain! his service done
At Lacedaemon and Byzantium.
Were a sufficient briber for his life.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: Why, I say, my lords, he's done fair service,
And slain in fight many of your enemies:
How full of valour did he bear himself
In the last conflict, and made plenteous wounds!

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.l: He has made too much plenty with 'em;
He's a sworn rioter: he has a sin that often
Drowns him, and takes his valour prisoner:
If there were no foes, that were enough
To overcome him: in that beastly fury
He has been known to commit outrages,
And cherish factions: 'tis inferred to us,
His days are foul and his drink dangerous.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: He dies.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: Hard fate! he might have died in war.
My lords, if not for any parts in him —
Though his right arm might purchase his own time
And be in debt to none — yet, more to move you,
Take my deserts to his, and join 'em both:
And, for I know your reverend ages love
Security, I'll pawn my victories, all
My honour to you, upon his good returns.
If by this crime he owes the law his life,
Why, let the war receive't in valiant gore;
For law is strict, and war is nothing more.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: We are for law: he dies; urge it no more,
On height of our displeasure: friend or brother,
He forfeits his own blood that spills another.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: Must it be so? it must not be. My lords,
I do beseech you, know me.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: Call me to your remembrances.

sp.speaker: Third Senator
sp.l: What!

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: I cannot think but your age has forgot me;
It could not else be, I should prove so base,
To sue, and be denied such common grace:
My wounds ache at you.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: Do you dare our anger?
'Tis in few words, but spacious in effect;
We banish thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: Banish me!
Banish your dotage; banish usury,
That makes the senate ugly.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: If, after two days' shine, Athens contain thee,
Attend our weightier judgement. And, not to swell our spirit,
He shall be executed presently. Exeunt Senators.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: Now the gods keep you old enough; that you may live
Only in bone, that none may look on you!
I'm worse than mad: I have kept back their foes,
While they have told their money and let out
Their coin upon large interest, I myself
Rich only in large hurts. All those for this?
Is this the balsam that the usuring senate
Pours into captains' wounds? Banishment!
It comes not ill; I hate not to be banished;
It is a cause worthy my spleen and fury,
That I may strike at Athens. I'll cheer up
My discontented troops, and lay for hearts.
'Tis honour with most lands to be at odds;
Soldiers should brook as little wrongs as gods. Exit.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 6
div.stage: The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house. Music. Tables set out: Servants attending.
Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: The good time of day to you, sir.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: I also wish it to you. I think this honourable lord
did but try us this other day.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Upon that were my thoughts tiring, when we
encountered: I hope it is not so low with him as
he made it seem in the trial of his several friends.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: It should not be, by the persuasion of his new
feasting.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: I should think so: he hath sent me an earnest
inviting, which many my near occasions did urge
me to put off; but he hath conjured me beyond them,
and I must needs appear.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: In like manner was I in debt to my importunate
business, but he would not hear my excuse. I am
sorry, when he sent to borrow of me, that my provision
was out.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: I am sick of that grief, too, as I understand how all
things go.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Every man here's so. What would he have borrowed of
you?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: A thousand pieces.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: A thousand pieces!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: What of you?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: He sent to me, sir, — Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: With all my heart, gentlemen both; and how fare you?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Ever at the best, hearing well of your lordship.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: The swallow follows not summer more willing than we
your lordship.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Nor more willingly leaves Winter; such summer
birds are men. Gentlemen, our dinner will not
recompense this long stay: feast your ears with
the music awhile, if they will fare so harshly o' the
trumpet's sound; we shall to't presently.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: I hope it remains not unkindly with your lordship that
I returned you an empty messenger.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: O, sir, let it not trouble you.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: My noble lord, —

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Ah, my good friend, what cheer?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: My most honourable lord, I am e'en sick of shame,
that, when your lordship this other day sent to me, I
was so unfortunate a beggar.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Think not on't, sir.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: If you had sent but two hours before, —

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Let it not cumber your better remembrance.
Come, bring in all together.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: All covered dishes!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Royal cheer, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.ab: Doubt not that, if money and the season can yield it.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: How do you? What's the news?

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.ab: Alcibiades is banished: hear you of it?

sp.speaker: First and Second Lords
sp.ab: Alcibiades banished!

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.ab: 'Tis so, be sure of it.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: How! how!

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: I pray you, upon what?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: My worthy friends, will you draw near?

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.ab: I'll tell you more anon. Here's a noble feast toward.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: This is the old man still.

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.ab: Will't hold? will't hold?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: It does: but time will — and so —

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.ab: I do conceive.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.ab: Each man to his stool, with that spur as he would
to the lip of his mistress: your diet shall be
in all places alike. Make not a city feast of
it, to let the meat cool ere we can agree upon
the first place: sit, sit. The gods require our
thanks. You great benefactors, sprinkle our
society with thankfulness. For your own gifts,
make yourselves praised: but reserve still to
give, lest your deities be despised. Lend to each
man enough, that one need not lend to another;
for, were your godheads to borrow of men, men
would forsake the gods. Make the meat be beloved
more than the man that gives it. Let no assembly
of twenty be without a score of villains: if
there sit twelve women at the table, let a dozen
of them be — as they are. The rest of your fees,
O gods — the senators of Athens, together with the
common lag of people — what is amiss in them, you
gods, make suitable for destruction. For these
my present friends, as they are to me nothing,
so in nothing bless them, and to nothing are they
welcome. Uncover, dogs, and lap.
sp.stage: The dishes are uncovered and seem to be full of warm water.

sp.speaker: Some
sp.ab: What does his lordship mean?

sp.speaker: Some
sp.ab: I know not.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: May you a better feast never behold,
You knot of mouth-friends! smoke and lukewarm water
Is your perfection. This is Timon's last;
Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries,
Washes it off, and sprinkles in your faces
Your reeking villainy. Throwing the water in their faces. Live loathed and long,
Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites,
Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears,
You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time's flies,
Cap-and-knee slaves, vapours, and minutejacks!
Of man and beast the infinite malady
Crust you quite o'er! What, dost thou go?
Soft! take thy physic first — thou too — and thou; —
Stay, I will lend thee money, borrow none. Throws the dishes at them, and drives them out.
What, all in motion? Henceforth be no feast,
Whereat a villain's not a welcome guest.
Burn, house! sink, Athens! henceforth hated be
Of Timon man and all humanity! Exit. Re-enter the Lords, Senators, c.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: How now, my lords!

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Know you the quality of Lord Timon's fury?

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.ab: Push! did you see my cap?

sp.speaker: Fourth Lord
sp.ab: I have lost my gown.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: He's but a mad lord, and nought but humours sways
him. He gave me a jewel th' other day, and now
he has beat it out of my hat: did you see my jewel?

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.ab: Did you see my cap?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.ab: Here 'tis.

sp.speaker: Fourth Lord
sp.ab: Here lies my gown.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Let's make no stay.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: Lord Timon's mad.

sp.speaker: Third Lord
sp.l: I feel't upon my bones.

sp.speaker: Fourth Lord
sp.l: One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 1
div.stage: Without the walls of Athens.
Enter TIMON.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: Let me look back upon thee. O thou wall,
That girdles in those wolves, dive in the earth,
And fence not Athens! Matrons, turn incontinent!
Obedience fail in children! slaves and fools,
Pluck the grave wrinkled senate from the bench,
And minister in their steads! to general filths
Convert o' the instant, green virginity,
Do't in your parents' eyes! bankrupts, hold fast;
Rather than render back, out with your knives,
And cut your trusters' throats! bound servants, steal!
Large-handed robbers your grave masters are,
And pill by law. Maid, to thy master's bed;
Thy mistress is o' the brothel! Son of sixteen,
Pluck the lined crutch from thy old limping sire,
With it beat out his brains! Piety, and fear,
Religion to the gods, peace, justice, truth,
Domestic awe, night-rest, and neighbourhood,
Instruction, manners, mysteries, and trades,
Degrees, observances, customs, and laws,
Decline to your confounding contraries.
And yet confusion live! Plagues, incident to men,
Your potent and infectious fevers heap
On Athens, ripe for stroke! Thou cold sciatica,
Cripple our senators, that their limbs may halt
As lamely as their manners! Lust and liberty
Creep in the minds and marrows of our youth,
That 'gainst the stream of virtue they may strive,
And drown themselves in riot! Itches, blains,
Sow all the Athenian bosoms; and their crop
Be general leprosy! Breath infect breath,
That their society, as their friendship, may
Be merely poison! Nothing I'll bear from thee,
But nakedness, thou detestable town!
Take thou that too, with multiplying bans
Timon will to the woods; where he shall find
The unkindest beast more kinder than mankind.
The gods confound — hear me, you good gods all —
The Athenians both within and out that wall!
And grant, as Timon grows, his hate may grow
To the whole race of mankind, high and low!
Amen. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 2
div.stage: Athens. A room in Timon's house.
Enter FLAVIUS, with two or three Servants.

sp.speaker: First Servant
sp.l: Hear you, master steward, where's our master?
Are we undone? cast off? nothing remaining?

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: Alack, my fellows, what should I say to you?
Let me be recorded by the righteous gods,
I am as poor as you.

sp.speaker: First Servant
sp.l: Such a house broke!
So noble a master fall'n! All gone! and not
One friend to take his fortune by the arm,
And go along with him!

sp.speaker: Second Servant
sp.l: As we do turn our backs
From our companion thrown into his grave,
So his familiars to his buried fortunes
Slink all away, leave their false vows with him,
Like empty purses picked; and his poor self,
A dedicated beggar to the air,
With his disease of all-shunned poverty,
Walks, like contempt, alone. More of our fellows. Enter other Servants.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: All broken implements of a ruined house.

sp.speaker: Third Servant
sp.l: Yet do our hearts wear Timon's livery;
That see I by our faces; we are fellows still,
Serving alike in sorrow: leaked is our bark,
And we, poor mates, stand on the dying deck,
Hearing the surges threat: we must all part
Into this sea of air.

sp.speaker: Flavius
sp.l: Good fellows all,
The latest of my wealth I'll share amongst you.
Where ever we shall meet, for Timon's sake,
Let's yet be fellows; let's shake our heads, and say,
As 'twere a knell unto our master's fortunes,
“We have seen better days.” Let each take some;
Nay, put out all your hands. Not one word more:
Thus part we rich in sorrow, parting poor. Servants embrace, and part several ways.
O, the fierce wretchedness that glory brings us!
Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt,
Since riches point to misery and contempt?
Who would be so mocked with glory? or to live
But in a dream of friendship?
To have his pomp and all what state compounds
But only painted, like his varnished friends?
Poor honest lord, brought low by his own heart,
Undone by goodness! Strange, unusual blood,
When man's worst sin is, he does too much good!
Who, then, dares to be half so kind again?
For bounty, that makes gods, do still mar men,
My dearest lord, blessed, to be most accursed,
Rich, only to be wretched, thy great fortunes
Are made thy chief afflictions. Alas, kind lord!
He's flung in rage from this ingrateful seat
Of monstrous friends, nor has he with him to
Supply his life, or that which can command it.
I'll follow and inquire him out:
I'll ever serve his mind with my best will;
Whilst I have gold, I'll be his steward still. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 3
div.stage: Woods and cave, near the sea-shore.
Enter TIMON, from the cave.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: O blessed breeding sun, draw from the earth
Rotten humidity; below thy sister's orb
Infect the air! Twinned brothers of one womb,
Whose procreation, residence, and birth,
Scarce is dividant, touch them with several fortunes;
The greater scorns the lesser: not nature,
To whom all sores lay siege, can bear great fortune;
But by contempt of nature.
Raise me this beggar, and deny't that lord;
The senator shall bear contempt hereditary,
The beggar native honour.
It is the pasture lards the brother's sides,
The want that makes him lean. Who dares, who dares,
In purity of manhood stand upright,
And say “This man's a flatterer”? if one be,
So are they all; for every grise of fortune
Is smoothed by that below: the learned pate
Ducks to the golden fool: all's obliquy;
There's nothing level in our cursed natures,
But direct villainy. Therefore, be abhorred
All feasts, societies, and throngs of men!
His semblable, yea, himself, Timon disdains:
Destruction fang mankind! Earth, yield me roots! Digging.
Who seeks for better of thee, sauce his palate
With thy most operant poison! What is here?
Gold? yellow, glittering, precious gold? No, gods,
I am no idle votarist: roots, you clear heavens
Thus much of this will make black white, foul fair,
Wrong right, base noble, old young, coward valiant.
Ha, you gods! why this? what this, you gods? Why, this
Will lug your priests and servants from your sides,
Pluck stout men's pillows from below their heads:
This yellow slave
Will knit and break religions, bless the accursed,
Make the hoar leprosy adored, place thieves
And give them title, knee and approbation
With senators on the bench: this is it
That makes the wappened widow wed again;
She, whom the spital-house and ulcerous sores
Would cast the gorge at, this embalms and spices
To the April day again. Come, damned earth,
Thou common whore of mankind, that puts odds
Among the rout of nations, I will make thee
Do thy right nature. March afar off.
Ha! a drum? Th' art quick,
But yet I'll bury thee: thou't go, strong thief,
When gouty keepers of thee cannot stand.
Nay, stay thou out for earnest. Keeping some gold. Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: What art thou there? speak.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: A beast, as thou art. The canker gnaw thy heart,
For showing me again the eyes of man!

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: What is thy name? Is man so hateful to thee,
That art thyself a man?

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: I am Misanthropos, and hate mankind.
For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dog,
That I might love thee something.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.l: I know thee well;
But in thy fortunes am unlearned and strange.

sp.speaker: Timon
sp.l: I know thee too; and more than that I know thee,
I not desire to know. Follow thy drum;
With man's blood paint the ground, gules, gules:
